body:
Create logical masks, multiply them by the chosen output for that logical condition, and then add them all together.

For example, suppose you want
```
y = 10   if x = 0
    -4.2 if x = 1
    14   if x = 2
```

Then in mxnet
```
x = mx.sym.var('x')
y = 10 * (x == 0) + -4.2 * (x == 1) + 14 * (x == 2)
```

This works because mxnet's logical operators return numeric 1/0 values (rather than boolean values). Consequently, each term in the above expression will be zero *except* the condition matching the value of x. So if x = 1, then the result of that operation is: `10 * 0 + -4.2 * 1 + 14 * 0 = -4.2`.

Same of course works if you're using mxnet ndarrays.

You might need broadcast_mul if you're working over a batch rather than the `*` operator.
I can document 2-5.

I can share 130-145 with @moontails. Let me know which ones would you prefer that I do.

@piiswrong do we need to document 146 BaseRNNCell._get_activation and 147 FusedRNNCell._slice_weights? These are not intended for use other than by the APIs.

OK, my intention is to estimate the mean of each constant. The data has many variables p in x
```
y    x[,1]    x[,2]    ...    x[,p]
10    0        1       ...     2
-4.2  1        1       ...     1
8.5   0        0       ...     1
-1    1        1       ...     2
5.9   0        2       ...     0
0.5   2        2       ...     1
```

Any suggestions how to deal with that? My first goal is simply to model as a linear regression.

If I'm understanding you, I would just restructure your data to be binary inputs which is far more standard for this kind of setup than special cases when you might really want to go through the trouble of defining piece-wise functions. 

In the case when you have 1 variable x in {0, 1, 2} then transform your input to be a 1 hot vector. For example, 
`x = 0` becomes `[1, 0, 0]`, 
`x = 1` becomes `[0, 1, 0]`,
`x = 2` becomes `[0, 0, 1]`.

If you have 2 variables, x in {0, 1, 2}^2, then you basically concatenate two one-hot vectors. For example,
`x = [2, 0]` becomes `[0, 0, 1, 1, 0, 0]`,
`x = [1, 2]` becomes `[0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1]`,
etc.

Extend for x in {0, 1, 2}^p for arbitrary p.

After pre-processing your input in this way, just add a FullyConnected layer to it and your favorite loss function.

You may want to look into using mxnet's [one_hot](http://mxnet.io/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.one_hot) function for helping with the pre-processing (or you can do it manually pretty easily), possibly with a reshaping afterwards.

what is your complete code, you should post a minimum working example

def gen_caffe_net():
    input=mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    ip1=mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=input, name="ip1", num_hidden=3)
    relu1=mx.symbol.Activation(data=ip1, act_type="relu", name="relu1")
    ip5=mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=relu1, name="ip5", num_hidden=2)
    net=mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=ip5, name="softmax1111")
    print net.debug_str()
    return net

sudo apt-get install libatlas-base-dev

@liumilan , In my system, you can give any name to the SoftmaxOutput.  The following code runs without error:
```
input=mx.symbol.Variable('data')
ip1=mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=input, name="ip1", num_hidden=3)
relu1=mx.symbol.Activation(data=ip1, act_type="relu", name="relu1")
ip5=mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=relu1, name="ip5", num_hidden=2)
net=mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=ip5, name="softmax1111")
```
What is your MXNet version? I am using version 0.9.4

This is as designed: you can have more layers after the ctc loss layer, which allows things like example weighting (this is not possible with the WarpCTC plugin, for example). Thus it requires an output grad during binding (like almost all other layers), or a `make_loss`, like @piiswrong suggested.

@precedenceguo , @piiswrong

Ok then could you disable ctc_loss when using warp ctc plugin first? We don't want to break existing features. also make sure all the copied ctc/modern gpu code is not in include path.
Also could you rename ctc_loss to _contrib_ctc_loss? so that it goes into mx.sym.contrib.

Sure, I will do those things.

For disabling: how would you recommend I do this?

I'm actually not sure.
One way I can think of is making this another plugin. Otherwise the .cc files will always be compiled unless you guard everyone with macros.

I think the problem here is you have two implementations of the same function (one from original baiductc.so, one from absorbed code). One solution I can think of is to wrap all absorbed ctc code in a different namespace.
I do think it shouldn't be too hard to fix (eg with namespaces). But its annoying that I can't build MXNet on GPU at the moment due to the OSX bug.
